Definition: Male breast cancer is a rare type of cancer that develops in the breast tissue of men.
Causes: Genetic mutations, family history, and exposure to radiation.
Symptoms: Lump in the breast, changes in breast shape, and discharge from the nipple.
Treatment: Surgery, chemotherapy, radiation therapy, and hormone therapy.

Definition: Male pattern baldness is a common form of hair loss in men, characterized by a receding hairline and thinning crown.
Causes: Genetic factors and hormonal changes.
Symptoms: Gradual thinning of hair on the scalp.
Treatment: Medications like minoxidil and finasteride, and hair transplant surgery.

Definition: Malignant peripheral nerve sheath tumors are rare cancers that develop in the protective lining of the nerves.
Causes: Genetic conditions like neurofibromatosis and exposure to radiation.
Symptoms: Pain, swelling, and neurological symptoms depending on the nerve affected.
Treatment: Surgery, chemotherapy, and radiation therapy.

Definition: Marfan syndrome is a genetic disorder that affects the body's connective tissue.
Causes: Genetic mutations in the FBN1 gene.
Symptoms: Tall stature, long limbs, and cardiovascular issues.
Treatment: Monitoring and management of symptoms, and surgery for heart issues.

Definition: Mastoiditis is an infection of the mastoid bone located behind the ear.
Causes: Untreated ear infections and sinus infections.
Symptoms: Ear pain, swelling behind the ear, and fever.
Treatment: Antibiotics and sometimes surgery to drain the infection.

Definition: MRKH syndrome is a congenital condition characterized by the absence of the uterus and the upper two-thirds of the vagina.
Causes: Exact cause is unknown, but it is a developmental disorder.
Symptoms: Absence of menstruation and infertility.
Treatment: Surgical creation of a vaginal canal and management of reproductive health.

Definition: Mediastinal tumors are abnormal growths located in the mediastinum, the area between the lungs.
Causes: Exact cause is often unknown; may include genetic factors.
Symptoms: Chest pain, cough, and difficulty breathing.
Treatment: Surgery, chemotherapy, and radiation therapy.

Definition: Melanoma is a type of skin cancer that develops from melanocytes, the cells that produce pigment.
Causes: Excessive sun exposure, tanning beds, and genetic factors.
Symptoms: Changes in existing moles, new growths, and skin lesions.
Treatment: Surgery, immunotherapy, targeted therapy, and radiation therapy.

Definition: Memory loss is the inability to remember information or experiences.
Causes: Aging, head injuries, and neurological disorders.
Symptoms: Forgetfulness, confusion, and difficulty recalling information.
Treatment: Depends on the underlying cause; may include cognitive therapy and medications.

Definition: Meniere's disease is a disorder of the inner ear that can lead to vertigo, hearing loss, and tinnitus.
Causes: Exact cause is unknown, but may involve fluid buildup in the inner ear.
Symptoms: Episodes of vertigo, ringing in the ears, and hearing loss.
Treatment: Dietary changes, medications, and sometimes surgery.

Definition: Meningioma is a tumor that arises from the meninges, the protective layers surrounding the brain and spinal cord.
Causes: Exact cause is unknown, but may involve genetic factors.
Symptoms: Headaches, seizures, and neurological deficits.
Treatment: Surgery, radiation therapy, and monitoring.

Definition: Meningitis is an inflammation of the protective membranes covering the brain and spinal cord.
Causes: Bacterial, viral, or fungal infections.
Symptoms: Fever, headache, stiff neck, and sensitivity to light.
Treatment: Antibiotics for bacterial meningitis and supportive care.

Definition: Meniscus tears are injuries to the cartilage in the knee joint.
Causes: Twisting motions, sports injuries, and degenerative changes.
Symptoms: Knee pain, swelling, and difficulty moving the knee.
Treatment: Rest, ice, physical therapy, and sometimes surgery.

Definition: Mesothelioma is a rare cancer that affects the lining of the lungs, abdomen, or heart, often caused by asbestos exposure.
Causes: Asbestos exposure and genetic factors.
Symptoms: Chest pain, shortness of breath, and abdominal swelling.
Treatment: Surgery, chemotherapy, and radiation therapy.

Definition: Metabolic acidosis is a condition characterized by an excess of acid in the body due to metabolic processes.
Causes: Diabetes, kidney disease, and severe diarrhea.
Symptoms: Fatigue, confusion, and rapid breathing.
Diagnosis: Blood tests measuring pH and bicarbonate levels.
Treatment: Addressing the underlying cause and sometimes bicarbonate therapy.

Definition: Metastatic breast cancer is breast cancer that has spread to other parts of the body.
Causes: Progression of untreated or recurrent breast cancer.
Symptoms: Bone pain, shortness of breath, and swelling.
Treatment: Chemotherapy, targeted therapy, and palliative care.

Definition: Metastatic melanoma is melanoma that has spread from the skin to other parts of the body.
Causes: Progression of untreated or recurrent melanoma.
Symptoms: New lumps, pain, and changes in existing moles.
Treatment: Immunotherapy, targeted therapy, and chemotherapy.

Definition: MRSA is a type of staph bacteria that is resistant to many antibiotics.
Causes: Infection with MRSA bacteria, often acquired in healthcare settings.
Symptoms: Red, swollen, painful areas on the skin, fever, and pus.
Treatment: Antibiotics effective against MRSA and drainage of abscesses.

Definition: Migraine is a neurological condition characterized by recurrent headaches, often accompanied by nausea and sensitivity to light.
Causes: Genetic factors, hormonal changes, and environmental triggers.
Symptoms: Severe headache, nausea, vomiting, and sensitivity to light and sound.
Treatment: Pain relief medications, preventive treatments, and lifestyle changes.

Definition: Mitral stenosis is a narrowing of the mitral valve opening, affecting blood flow from the left atrium to the left ventricle.
Causes: Rheumatic fever and congenital heart defects.
Symptoms: Shortness of breath, fatigue, and palpitations.
Treatment: Medications and surgical procedures to repair or replace the valve.

Definition: Mitral valve prolapse is a condition where the mitral valve does not close properly, allowing blood to leak backward.
Causes: Genetic factors and connective tissue disorders.
Symptoms: Palpitations, chest pain, and fatigue.
Treatment: Monitoring, medications, and surgery in severe cases.

Definition: Mitral valve regurgitation is a condition where the mitral valve does not close tightly, allowing blood to flow backward into the left atrium.
Causes: Rheumatic heart disease, mitral valve prolapse, and heart attack.
Symptoms: Shortness of breath, fatigue, and heart palpitations.
Treatment: Medications and surgical repair or replacement of the valve.

Definition: Mouth cancer, or oral cancer, refers to cancer that develops in the tissues of the mouth.
Causes: Tobacco use, alcohol consumption, and HPV infection.
Symptoms: Sores in the mouth, difficulty swallowing, and changes in voice.
Treatment: Surgery, radiation therapy, and chemotherapy.

Definition: Moyamoya disease is a rare cerebrovascular disorder characterized by the narrowing of the arteries at the base of the brain.
Causes: Exact cause is unknown, but it may have a genetic component.
Symptoms: Transient ischemic attacks (TIAs), strokes, and headaches.
Diagnosis: Imaging studies such as MRI and angiography.
Treatment: Surgical revascularization and management of symptoms.

Definition: Mpox, formerly known as monkeypox, is a viral disease that causes flu-like symptoms and a distinctive rash.
Causes: Infection with the mpox virus, which is related to smallpox.
Symptoms: Fever, headache, muscle aches, and rash.
Treatment: Supportive care and antiviral medications in severe cases.

Definition: Mucosal melanoma is a rare type of melanoma that occurs in mucous membranes.
Causes: Exact cause is unknown, but may involve genetic factors.
Symptoms: Pigmented lesions in the mouth, nose, or other mucosal areas.
Treatment: Surgery, chemotherapy, and immunotherapy.

Definition: Mullerian anomalies are congenital abnormalities of the female reproductive tract.
Causes: Developmental issues during fetal growth.
Symptoms: Menstrual irregularities, infertility, and pelvic pain.
Treatment: Depends on the specific anomaly; may include surgery and reproductive assistance.

Definition: Multiple endocrine neoplasia is a group of disorders that affect the endocrine system and lead to tumors in multiple glands.
Causes: Genetic mutations, often inherited.
Symptoms: Varies by type; may include hormonal imbalances and tumors.
Treatment: Monitoring, surgery, and management of hormone levels.

Definition: Multiple myeloma is a cancer of plasma cells in the bone marrow.
Causes: Exact cause is unknown, but may involve genetic factors.
Symptoms: Bone pain, anemia, and kidney dysfunction.
Diagnosis: Blood tests, imaging studies, and bone marrow biopsy.
Treatment: Chemotherapy, targeted therapy, and stem cell transplant.

Definition: Multiple sclerosis is a chronic autoimmune disease that affects the central nervous system.
Causes: Exact cause is unknown, but involves immune system attacks on myelin.
Symptoms: Fatigue, vision problems, and difficulty with coordination.
Diagnosis: MRI, lumbar puncture, and neurological examination.
Treatment: Disease-modifying therapies, symptom management, and rehabilitation.

Definition: Multiple system atrophy is a rare neurodegenerative disorder that affects the autonomic nervous system and movement.
Causes: Exact cause is unknown, but involves abnormal protein accumulation in the brain.
Symptoms: Parkinsonism, balance issues, and autonomic dysfunction.
Treatment: Symptomatic management and supportive care.

Definition: Mumps is a viral infection that primarily affects the salivary glands.
Causes: Infection with the mumps virus.
Symptoms: Swollen salivary glands, fever, and headache.
Treatment: Supportive care and vaccination for prevention.

Definition: Muscular dystrophy is a group of genetic disorders characterized by progressive muscle weakness and degeneration.
Causes: Genetic mutations affecting muscle proteins.
Symptoms: Muscle weakness, difficulty walking, and muscle wasting.
Diagnosis: Genetic testing, muscle biopsy, and clinical evaluation.
Treatment: Physical therapy, medications, and supportive care.

Definition: Myasthenia gravis is a chronic autoimmune disorder that causes weakness in the skeletal muscles.
Causes: Autoimmune response affecting the communication between nerves and muscles.
Symptoms: Muscle weakness, fatigue, and difficulty with eye movements.
Diagnosis: Clinical evaluation, blood tests, and electromyography.
Treatment: Medications, plasmapheresis, and thymectomy.

Definition: Myelodysplastic syndromes are a group of disorders caused by poorly formed or dysfunctional blood cells.
Causes: Genetic mutations and exposure to certain chemicals or radiation.
Symptoms: Fatigue, frequent infections, and easy bruising.
Diagnosis: Blood tests and bone marrow biopsy.
Treatment: Supportive care, medications, and stem cell transplant.

Definition: Myelopathy is a neurological condition caused by compression or damage to the spinal cord.
Causes: Herniated discs, spinal stenosis, and trauma.
Symptoms: Weakness, numbness, and coordination problems.
Treatment: Physical therapy, medications, and sometimes surgery.

Definition: Myeloproliferative neoplasms are a group of blood cancers that cause the bone marrow to produce too many blood cells.
Causes: Genetic mutations, often acquired.
Symptoms: Fatigue, night sweats, and splenomegaly.
Diagnosis: Blood tests and bone marrow biopsy.
Treatment: Medications, phlebotomy, and sometimes stem cell transplant.

Definition: Myocarditis is an inflammation of the heart muscle, which can affect its ability to pump blood.
Causes: Viral infections, autoimmune diseases, and exposure to toxins.
Symptoms: Chest pain, fatigue, and shortness of breath.
Diagnosis: Imaging studies, blood tests, and biopsy.
Treatment: Medications, lifestyle changes, and management of underlying causes.

Definition: Myopathy is a disease of the muscle tissue that leads to muscle weakness.
Causes: Genetic factors, autoimmune diseases, and certain medications.
Symptoms: Muscle weakness, cramps, and fatigue.
Diagnosis: Blood tests, muscle biopsy, and imaging studies.
Treatment: Depends on the underlying cause; may include medications and physical therapy.

Definition: Myositis is inflammation of the muscles, which can lead to weakness and pain.
Causes: Autoimmune diseases, infections, and certain medications.
Symptoms: Muscle weakness, pain, and swelling.
Diagnosis: Blood tests, muscle biopsy, and imaging studies.
Treatment: Corticosteroids, immunosuppressive medications, and physical therapy.

Definition: Myxofibrosarcoma is a rare type of soft tissue sarcoma that typically occurs in the extremities.
Causes: Exact cause is unknown, but may involve genetic mutations.
Symptoms: A lump or mass, pain, and swelling.
Treatment: Surgery, radiation therapy, and chemotherapy.
